I thought the film was pretty, and the kendo sequences well staged, but the=
 whole thing was a bit tough to swallow.  I'm afraid I agree with the Wall =
Street Journal's critic that it was impossible to identify any possible rat=
ional political agenda that all these samurai were bravely dying to effectu=
ate.

Nathan Algren (Tom Cruise) is hired to go to Japan to train the Imper=
ial troops, in the first place, by Colonel Bagley his cynical, corrupt and =
unlovable former superior officer.  When Algren returns to the city from hi=
s sojourn in Katsumoto's Shangri-La prefecture, Bagley, upon learning that =
Algren has switched loyalties, has the best line of the movie. "Why do you =
hate your own people?"  he inquires.  Cruise and Zwick never answer that qu=
estion, and I wonder why.  Algren is consumed throughout the film by remors=
e for participation in phallocratic, Imperialist, European attacks upon inn=
ocent, harmless, unoffending Native Americans, who obviously would not them=
selves have hurt a fly.  We are given to understand that Bagley and Algren =
and their cavalry killed Indian women and children, since Little Big Man, f=
rom Hollywood's perspective the distinctive crime of late 19th century US c=
avalrymen.    We all know that Indians, of course, never ever made war upon=
 women or children.  

Algren is, at the beginning of the film, a drunk, bu=
t his capture and assimilation by the noble samurai cures him of drinking. =
 They cure him by adopting him into a new trans-Pacific tribe of nobler-tha=
n-thou primitives, who possess a deeper and more profound understanding of =
nature, humanity, and ordinary living than us deracinated white-eyes.  Like=
 the American Indians, the samurai are vanishing in the face of an advancin=
g modernity, and Algren has found the cause which can redeem his corrupt Ca=
ucasian soul.

There are, alas! certain problems related to factual plausib=
ility, overlooked by the film's continuity department.  The samurai sensibi=
lity was certainly capable of admiring the bravery and skill of an adversar=
y, but it was not prone to capturing him alive and taking him home as a gue=
st.  Samurai mercy to a defeated enemy rose at its ultimate peak to letting=
 him commit seppuku.  Katsumoto supposedly spares Algren in order to "learn=
 about the West," but, in fact, his interest seems entirely to focus on Alg=
ren's personality, previous career, and on the Western Indians.  Katsumoto =
is presented as obviously not interested, or sympathetic to, in the West  i=
n general, despite having somehow acquired perfect English.  He simply want=
s to keep Japan free of Western influences, particularly free of Western te=
chnology.  I suppose he must have learned his English at the University of =
Oregon.

Bushido, as described in the Hagekure, the classic 17th century tr=
eatise on samurai ideals, basically consists of an eagerness to die honorab=
ly in one's master's service, and the sooner the better.  Edward Zwick's fi=
lm certainly has assimilated that sensibility.  Katsumoto and his band of b=
rothers apparently have no personal ambitions beyond demonstrating their cr=
otchetty Japanese conservatism, and suspicion of the consequences of Wester=
n influences and innovation, by putting up a good fight in the course of ge=
tting themselves killed facing overwhelmingly superior forces.

The fightin=
g is pure Hollywood.  In the midst of an evening's kabuki performance, Kats=
umoto naturally hops on stage and takes a comic turn in order to demonstrat=
e that the ascetic and war-like nobleman is not above clowning.  As he perf=
orms, ninja begin creeping over the rooftops to attempt his assassination. =
 Before long, Katsumoto and Algren and all the fighting men (and women) of =
the village are desperately fighting off the attack of roughly a regiment o=
f ninja.  Why it is that these highly skilled ninja, armed with all sorts o=
f specialized weaponry, need to creep up and try for a crossbow shot, when =
they've obviously got the whole town outnumbered in the first place seemed =
mysterious.  Nonetheless, naturally, the ninja lose.

In another oh-sure! f=
ighting scene, the unarmed Algren finds himself attacked by four armed assa=
ssins.  In a very nicely choreographed sequence, Algren eludes blows, disar=
ms some, and then kills all his opponents in a very impressive (if implausi=
ble) display of fighting arts.  Tom Cruise must have been rather proud of b=
eing able to do all this, since the sequence is repeated in slow motion for=
 our edification.  I was kind of wishing that John Madden were delivering a=
 voice over as I watched it the second time.

In the culminating grand batt=
le, Katsumoto and his band of one or two hundred stodgy, sword-wielding con=
servatives face one or two thousand Western-style Japanese infantry, armed =
with bolt-action repeating rifles and bayonets, supported by howitzers and =
Gatling guns.  The conservatives cleverly lure the first Imperial infantry =
regiment into a trap, just out of howitzer range, cutting them off from ret=
reat with a line of prepared incendiary devices, then successfully employin=
g combined arms tactics using archery, infantry, and cavalry to pull off a =
still very costly temporary victory.  Naturally, they do not stop there.  M=
uch reduced by casualties from the first stage of the battle, the noble sam=
urai mount their horses, and proceed to emulate the Light Brigade, undertak=
ing a cavalry charge directly into the face of the vastly numerically super=
ior remaining infantry regiment, and those howitzers, and those Gatling gun=
s.  Naturally, they all die.  Katsumoto, Algren, and every significant supp=
orting samurai are all shot repeatedly by Gatling guns firing, I presume, .=
45-70 rounds.  Though riddled with bullets, Katsumoto is so reboutable a sa=
murai that he requires Algen's assistance to die.  Algren is even more robu=
st.  He survives, and gets to deliver Katsumoto's sword to the Emperor in r=
eproach.  Overwhelmed by the beauty of the death of Katsumoto and all his l=
oyal retainers, the Emperor fires Katsumoto's political rival, cancels a tr=
eaty with the United States, and one supposes, rescinds the ban against wea=
ring swords, bans the gun, expells the Western barbarians, and returns Japa=
n to splendid isolation.  Japan consequently never invades Korea, defeats R=
ussia, and then goes after China.  Japan never builds a navy, never constru=
cts a Co-East Asia Prosperity Sphere, never attacks Pear Harbor, and everyo=
ne lives happily ever after.
